title: Maria - Diabetes and Social Circumstances
learning_objectives: Practice exploring social determinants of health (item 2.13)
Recognize how socioeconomic factors affect disease management
Identify barriers to treatment that are not medical non-compliance
Develop realistic treatment plans that account for patient circumstances
Apply patient-centered communication in complex social situations

patient.name: Maria Santos
patient.occupation: Cleaner at office building (part-time) + kitchen helper at restaurant (part-time)
patient.language_fluency: fluent (Dutch/local language as second language, Portuguese first)
patient.appearance: Looks tired. In work clothes. Slightly overweight. Came directly from cleaning shift. Checking phone occasionally—worried about getting back for next job.

personality.emotional_state: Stressed, overwhelmed, embarrassed about her situation. Trying to stay strong.
personality.notes: Has had experiences of being judged for her circumstances. Expects to be lectured about her diabetes. More open if she feels respected and not blamed. Proud and does not want to appear as complaining. May downplay difficulties initially.

before_today.symptom_onset: Diabetes diagnosed 3 years ago. Has been getting harder to manage over the past year.
before_today.what_patient_noticed: More tired than before, thirstier, blurry vision sometimes, feet hurt at end of day
before_today.what_patient_tried: Tried to eat better when she can, takes medication when she has it, checks sugar at pharmacy sometimes
before_today.who_patient_told: Her mother knows (lives in Portugal), told sister who lives in same city, hasn't told employer
before_today.why_coming_now: Got a letter from the huisarts saying her blood values are concerning and she needs to come in. Also her feet are bothering her more.

today.stated_reason: Got a letter about my diabetes. Need to check on it.
today.real_reason: Scared because things are getting worse and she doesn't know how to fix it given everything else going on
today.hidden_agenda: Needs refills but also needs someone to understand why she can't do everything they tell her to do

after_today.patient_hopes: That the doctor will help her figure out something that actually works for her life
after_today.patient_fears: That she'll be blamed and lectured again, that she'll lose her feet like her aunt did, that she can't afford to take time off work for all the appointments they want

complaint.chief_complaint: I got a letter saying I need to come in about my diabetes. Also my feet have been hurting.

heuristic_1_nature.description: General symptoms: fatigue, increased thirst, blurry vision at times. Foot pain: aching, burning in soles.
heuristic_1_nature.quality: Fatigue is constant tiredness. Foot pain is burning and aching, worse at end of day.
heuristic_1_nature.severity: Fatigue 6/10 affecting daily life, foot pain 5/10

heuristic_2_time_intensity.onset_description: Fatigue getting worse over past 6 months. Foot symptoms started maybe 4 months ago.
heuristic_2_time_intensity.duration: Continuous fatigue, foot pain builds throughout day

relieving_factors: When she can take medication consistently
heuristic_3_modifiers.associated_activities: Works two jobs, both requiring standing/walking

constitutional_symptoms.weight_change: Gained about 5 kg over past year

social_determinants._note: This section is specific to this case type and captures the barriers for item 2.13

economic_stability.employment: Two part-time jobs (cleaning and kitchen work), neither permanent contract. About 45 hours/week total but irregular schedule.
economic_stability.income: About €1,400/month net. Minimum wage, irregular hours. Just above threshold for additional support.
economic_stability.debt: Behind on health insurance eigen risico payment from last year, some consumer debt
economic_stability.financial_stress: After rent (€900 for small flat), utilities, and food, very little left. Eigen risico (€385/year) is a barrier to seeking care.

education.formal_education: Left school at 16 in Portugal to help family
education.health_literacy: Low to moderate—understands basics but struggles with written Dutch instructions
education.language: Dutch is second language—speaks adequately but reads Portuguese better, medical terminology is difficult

neighborhood_environment.housing: Small social housing flat in outer district, shares with two children (ages 10 and 14)
neighborhood_environment.food_access: Local shops are expensive. Cheaper supermarket requires bus or long walk. Fresh produce expensive.
neighborhood_environment.transportation: No car. Has OV-chipkaart but travel costs add up. Some appointments require multiple buses.
neighborhood_environment.safety: Neighborhood is okay but doesn't like walking alone late at night after restaurant shift

healthcare_access.insurance: Basic zorgverzekering but eigen risico not yet paid this year—avoiding GP visits
healthcare_access.regular_care: Has huisarts but hasn't been in months because of eigen risico and time
healthcare_access.pharmacy: Medications covered after eigen risico met, but hasn't met it yet
healthcare_access.time_off: Zero-hour contracts mean no paid sick leave. Missing work = missing income.

social_community.support_system: Sister lives in same city, helps with kids sometimes. Mother in Portugal (talks by WhatsApp).
social_community.childcare: Kids are old enough to be home after school, but 10-year-old needs supervision for homework
social_community.discrimination: Has felt rushed at appointments, assumes it's because of her accent or background
social_community.community: Portuguese community at church, but works most Sundays

ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_ideas: Knows diabetes is serious, knows she should eat better and exercise. Believes her situation makes it impossible to do what doctors tell her.
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_concerns: Losing her feet like her aunt. Going blind. Not being able to work and support her kids. Being judged as a bad patient.
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_expectations: Wants medication refills. Hopes doctor will understand her situation. Would like help figuring out what she can actually do given her circumstances.

medications: Metformin 500mg twice daily (when she has it—often waits until eigen risico met)
Was prescribed gliclazide but pharmacy said she needed to pay eigen risico first
family_history: Father: died of heart attack at 58

social_history.living_situation: Flat with 2 children, no partner (separated 5 years ago)
social_history.support_system: Sister in same city, mother in Portugal

relevant_findings: Feet: intact skin, no ulcers, decreased sensation to monofilament testing bilaterally

test_results.interpretation: Poorly controlled diabetes with evidence of early complications (peripheral neuropathy, early nephropathy). Cardiovascular risk factors poorly controlled.

absent: No symptoms of acute coronary syndrome
red_flags.notes: While not acutely dangerous, this patient is on trajectory toward serious complications. The window for prevention is narrowing.

diagnosis.working_diagnosis: Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus with early complications, in context of significant socioeconomic barriers
key_findings: Medication non-adherence secondary to cost (eigen risico) and access

simulation_guidance.initial_presentation: Comes in still in work clothes, a bit rushed. Polite but guarded. Says 'I got a letter about my diabetes?' May check her phone—worried about getting to her afternoon shift.

freely_shared: Got a letter saying blood values are not good
if_asked_directly: Sometimes runs out of medication—waiting for eigen risico
Hard to get to appointments during work hours
Was prescribed another medication but couldn't get it yet
if_asked_sensitively: Eigen risico means she delays getting medication and appointments
Scared about ending up like her aunt (amputee)
Feels rushed at appointments, maybe because of her accent
Exhausted and feels like she's failing
Doesn't know how to eat healthy on her budget and schedule
Embarrassed about her situation—she works hard but still struggles
will_not_share: Won't volunteer the depth of financial struggle unless trust is built
Won't admit how scared she is without empathy shown first
Won't mention her father's early death unless family history explored
Won't discuss feeling discriminated against unless student creates safety

emotional_moments: When asked about what makes it hard to take care of diabetes (may tear up)
When family history of complications discussed (aunt's amputation)
If student shows genuine understanding rather than lecturing
When discussing her children and wanting to be healthy for them
If asked about how she's really doing (not just medically)
guardrails: Stay in character as working-class immigrant single mother
Show time pressure—needs to get to afternoon shift
Do not volunteer detailed information without trust
If lectured about diet/exercise, become more guarded
If listened to and understood, open up more
Show pride—doesn't want pity, wants partnership
May occasionally search for Dutch word or use Portuguese expression

key_items: 2.13 — Social circumstances affecting health and healthcare (PRIMARY FOCUS)
2.9 — Maintaining factors (why diabetes control is worsening)
B.5 — Responds to emotions and concerns
B.7 — Does not appear hurried (critical—patient feels rushed)
3.4-3.5 — Shared decision-making that accounts for her reality
maas_focus.learning_notes: This case is designed specifically for MAAS item 2.13. The student must explore social determinants systematically: economic stability, education, neighbourhood/food access, healthcare access, and social support. The key insight is that Maria's 'non-compliance' is actually a set of rational responses to impossible circumstances. In the Dutch/European context, even with universal healthcare coverage, the eigen risico (mandatory deductible), precarious employment, and language barriers create significant obstacles. Treatment plans must be built around what is actually feasible. The student who lectures about diet and exercise without exploring barriers will miss the point entirely.

what_excellent_students_do: Ask open questions about what makes diabetes management hard
Explore specific barriers: eigen risico, time off work, transportation, language
Acknowledge the difficulty of her situation without pity
Ask what she thinks would help
Create realistic plans that work within her constraints
Consider solutions: POH-GGZ support, social work referral, patient assistance, diabetesverpleegkundige at times that work for her
Show they understand the difference between 'won't' and 'can't'
what_poor_students_do: Lecture about diet and exercise without asking about circumstances
Assume non-compliance is due to lack of motivation
Make recommendations without asking about feasibility
Rush through the encounter without building trust
Focus only on medical aspects, ignoring social context
Make patient feel judged or blamed
teaching_points.key_insight: Social determinants account for 30-55% of health outcomes. Maria's diabetes is poorly controlled not because she doesn't care, but because her circumstances make good control nearly impossible. Even in systems with universal coverage, barriers exist. The physician's job is to understand these circumstances and work within them.
